canonical_explanation.text: One-to-one correspondence means matching each object in one group to exactly one object in another group. For example, if there are 4 cups and 4 saucers, each cup goes on one saucer. This helps us compare groups and understand if they have the same number, more, or fewer objects.
rules: Each object in one group is paired with exactly one object in the other group.
No object is left without a pair if the groups are equal.
If one group has objects left over after matching, that group has more.
Matching objects one-to-one helps us tell which group has more, fewer, or the same number.

questions.question_text: There are 3 cups and 3 saucers. If we place each cup on one saucer, how many saucers will be left without a cup?
questions.explanation_correct: If there are 3 cups and 3 saucers, and each cup is placed on one saucer, then all the saucers will have a cup on them. So, there will be 0 saucers left without a cup.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is that 0 saucers will be left without a cup. This is because there are 3 cups and 3 saucers, and each cup is placed on one saucer. So, all the saucers will have a cup on them, and there will be no saucers left without a cup.

questions.question_text: You have 5 hats and 5 children. If each child wears one hat, how many hats are left over?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is D) 0 hats left over. This is because each of the 5 children gets 1 hat, so all 5 hats are worn by the children. There are no hats left over.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer is A) 5 hats left over. This is not correct because each of the 5 children gets 1 hat, so all 5 hats are used. There are no hats left over, since there is a one-to-one match between the hats and the children.

questions.question_text: One-to-one correspondence means:

options.text: Giving all objects to one person
Matching each object in one group to exactly one object in another group
Putting all objects in one pile

questions.explanation_correct: One-to-one correspondence means matching each object in one group to exactly one object in another group. This helps us make sure the two groups have the same number of objects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is the correct answer because one-to-one correspondence means that each object in one group is matched to exactly one object in another group. This is different from giving all the objects to one person (option A), putting all the objects in one pile (option C), or counting backwards (option D).

questions.question_text: Which pair goes together?
questions.explanation_correct: Shoe and foot go together because each foot needs a shoe. They match up one-to-one, with one shoe for each foot.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Shoe and foot go together because a shoe is worn on a foot. The other options, like hat, plate, and pencil, do not have a direct matching relationship with a shoe. They do not go together in a one-to-one way like a shoe and a foot do.

questions.question_text: There are 6 flowers and 4 vases. Each vase holds one flower. How many flowers will not have a vase?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 2. This is because there are 6 flowers and 4 vases, so 4 flowers will have a vase, and the remaining 2 flowers will not have a vase.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct. Option A) 1 is wrong because there are 2 flowers that do not have a vase. Option C) 3 is wrong because there are only 2 flowers that do not have a vase. Option D) 4 is wrong because all 4 vases have a flower in them, so only 2 flowers are left without a vase.

questions.question_text: Group A has 7 balls. Group B has 7 boxes. After matching one ball to one box, what can we say?

options.text: Both groups have the same number

questions.explanation_correct: Since Group A has 7 balls and Group B has 7 boxes, and we matched each ball to a box, then both groups have the same number of objects. This means they are equal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is that both groups have the same number. This is because there are 7 balls in Group A and 7 boxes in Group B, and we matched each ball to a box. This means the two groups have the same amount of objects, so they are equal.

questions.question_text: There are 8 plates and 5 spoons. Each plate needs one spoon. How many plates will not get a spoon?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 3. There are 8 plates and only 5 spoons. Since each plate needs one spoon, 3 plates will not get a spoon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer is C) 4. This is not correct because there are 8 plates and only 5 spoons. So, 3 plates will not get a spoon, not 4. The correct answer is B) 3 plates will not get a spoon.

questions.question_text: 4 dogs each need 1 bone. There are 6 bones. After giving one bone to each dog, how many extra bones are there?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) 2 extra bones. There are 4 dogs and each dog needs 1 bone. So, 4 bones are given to the dogs. Since there are 6 bones in total, there are 2 extra bones left over.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer is A) 0 extra bones. This is not correct because there are 6 bones, and only 4 dogs need 1 bone each. So, after giving 1 bone to each dog, there will be 2 extra bones left over.

questions.question_text: If every child in a row gets exactly one balloon, this is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: If every child gets exactly one balloon, this shows one-to-one matching. Each child is matched to one balloon, so the groups are equal in number.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The question is asking for an example of one-to-one matching, where each object in one group is matched to exactly one object in another group. Sorting means grouping objects by their features, subtraction means taking away some objects, and sharing unevenly means giving different amounts to different people. But when each child gets one balloon, that's an example of one-to-one matching, where the number of children and balloons are equal.

questions.question_text: Which object pairs best with a lock?
questions.explanation_correct: A key is the best match for a lock because a key fits perfectly into a lock. When you use a key to open a lock, it creates a one-to-one correspondence, where the key goes with the lock.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A spoon, hat, and ball do not match well with a lock. These items do not have a special connection to a lock like a key does. A key is designed to fit into a lock and unlock it, so it is the best pair for a lock.

questions.question_text: There are 10 chairs and 8 children. Each child sits on one chair. Which group has fewer?
questions.explanation_correct: The children group has fewer objects than the chairs group. Each child sits on one chair, so there are 8 children and 10 chairs. Since 8 is less than 10, the children group has fewer objects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is that the children group has fewer objects. Since each child sits on one chair, there are 8 children and 10 chairs. This means the children group has fewer objects than the chairs group. Option A (chairs) and Option C (both are equal) are not correct because there are more chairs than children.

questions.question_text: A teacher gives 1 pencil to each of 9 students. She has 12 pencils. How many pencils are left?
questions.explanation_correct: The teacher has 12 pencils and gives 1 pencil to each of 9 students. So, the number of pencils left is 12 - 9 = 3. This means the correct answer is B) 3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The teacher has 12 pencils and gives 1 pencil to each of 9 students. This means she gave away 9 pencils. To find the number of pencils left, we need to subtract 9 from 12, which gives us 3 pencils. Therefore, the correct answer is B) 3, not A) 2, C) 4, or D) 5.

questions.question_text: Matching objects one-to-one helps us learn to:
questions.explanation_correct: Matching objects one-to-one helps us learn to count and compare groups because it lets us see if the groups have the same number of things, more, or fewer. When we match cups to saucers, we can check if there are the same number of cups and saucers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Matching objects one-to-one does not help us learn to draw pictures, write letters, or sing songs. It is a way to count and compare groups to see how many things are in each group. Matching things one-to-one is a important step in learning to count and understand numbers.

questions.question_text: There are 4 birds and 4 nests. Each bird sits in one nest. Are there any empty nests?

options.text: No, all nests have a bird

questions.explanation_correct: Since there are 4 birds and 4 nests, and each bird sits in one nest, all the nests have a bird. There are no empty nests.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The question says there are 4 birds and 4 nests, and each bird sits in one nest. This means that all the nests have a bird in them. Option C, 'No, all nests have a bird', is the correct answer because there are no empty nests.

questions.question_text: There are 5 gloves and 3 hands. After matching one glove to each hand, how many gloves have no hand?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) 2 gloves have no hand. This is because there are 5 gloves and only 3 hands, so 2 gloves will not have a hand to match with.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer is A) 0 gloves have no hand. This is not correct because there are 5 gloves and only 3 hands, so 2 gloves will not have a hand to match with. The correct answer is C) 2 gloves have no hand.

questions.question_text: There are 4 cups and 4 saucers. Each cup is placed on one saucer. The number of cups and saucers is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The number of cups and saucers is equal because there are 4 cups and 4 saucers, and each cup is placed on one saucer. This means there is a one-to-one match between the cups and saucers, so the numbers are equal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'equal'. This is because there are 4 cups and 4 saucers, and each cup is placed on one saucer. This means the number of cups and the number of saucers are the same, or equal. The number of cups and saucers is not more or fewer, but equal.

questions.question_text: When each object in one group matches with exactly one object in another group, it is called one-to-___ correspondence.
questions.explanation_correct: When each object in one group matches with exactly one object in another group, it is called one-to-one correspondence. This means that there is a perfect match between the objects in the two groups, with no objects left over or missing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The missing word in the sentence is 'one'. One-to-one correspondence means that each object in one group is matched with exactly one object in the other group. The word 'one' is needed to complete the phrase and describe this matching process correctly.

questions.question_text: There are 6 apples and 4 baskets. Each basket gets one apple. ___ apples are left without a basket.
questions.explanation_correct: The answer is 2 because there are 6 apples and 4 baskets. Since each basket gets one apple, there are 2 apples left without a basket.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 2. There are 6 apples and 4 baskets. Each basket gets one apple, so 4 apples are taken. That means there are 6 - 4 = 2 apples left without a basket.

questions.question_text: A shoe pairs with a ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A shoe pairs with a foot because a shoe is always worn on a foot. This is an example of one-to-one correspondence, where each shoe matches exactly one foot.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'foot'. A shoe does not pair with a sock or a leg. Shoes are made to fit on our feet, so the correct match for a shoe is a foot. Remember, in one-to-one correspondence, each object in one group is matched to exactly one object in another group.

questions.question_text: There are 5 dogs and 8 bones. After giving one bone to each dog, ___ bones are left over.
questions.explanation_correct: There are 5 dogs and 8 bones. Since we give one bone to each dog, that means 5 bones are given to the dogs. The remaining 8 bones - 5 given away = 3 bones left over.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The question says there are 5 dogs and 8 bones. If we give one bone to each dog, that leaves 3 bones left over. The accepted answer format is a single number, so the correct answer is 3.

questions.question_text: There are 7 hats and 7 heads. After matching, ___ hats are left without a head.
questions.explanation_correct: The answer is 0 because there is a one-to-one correspondence between the 7 hats and the 7 heads. Each hat matches with one head, so there are no hats left without a head.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The answer is 0 hats left without a head. This is because there are 7 hats and 7 heads, and each hat matches with one head. Since there is a one-to-one correspondence, all the hats have a head to go on, and there are no hats left over.

questions.question_text: Matching one object to one object helps us get ready to ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Matching one object to one object helps us get ready to count because it lets us keep track of how many things we have. If each cup has a saucer, we can count the cups to know how many saucers we need.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The missing word is 'count'. When we match one object to one object, it helps us get ready to count the number of things we have. For example, if we have 4 cups and 4 saucers, we can match each cup to one saucer, and then we can count the total number of objects, which is 8.

questions.question_text: There are 3 kittens and 3 bowls of milk. Each kitten drinks from one bowl. The groups are ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The groups are equal because there are 3 kittens and 3 bowls of milk, and each kitten drinks from one bowl. This means that there is a one-to-one match between the kittens and the bowls, so the groups are equal in number.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'equal'. This is because there are 3 kittens and 3 bowls of milk, and each kitten drinks from one bowl. This means that the number of kittens and the number of bowls are the same, so the groups are equal. The wrong answer would be if there were more or fewer bowls than kittens.

questions.question_text: 10 children and 8 chairs. Each child needs one chair. ___ children will not get a chair.
questions.explanation_correct: Since there are 10 children and only 8 chairs, 2 children will not get a chair. This is because each child needs one chair, and there are fewer chairs than children.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 2 children, which is correct. There are 10 children and only 8 chairs, so 2 children will not get a chair. This is because each child needs one chair, and there are fewer chairs than children.

questions.question_text: A key pairs with a ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A key goes with a lock because they have a one-to-one relationship. Each key matches with one lock, and each lock has one key that fits it perfectly. This shows one-to-one correspondence between the key and the lock.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'lock'. A key does not go with a cup or a saucer - those would not show one-to-one correspondence. Keys and locks have a special relationship where each key fits one lock, and each lock has one key that opens it. This is an example of one-to-one correspondence.

questions.question_text: If there are 5 cups and 5 saucers, each cup can be placed on exactly one saucer with none left over.
questions.explanation_correct: If there are 5 cups and 5 saucers, then each cup can be placed on exactly one saucer. This is called one-to-one correspondence, where each object in one group is matched with one object in another group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true because one-to-one correspondence means that each object in one group is matched with exactly one object in another group. In this case, there are 5 cups and 5 saucers, so each cup can be placed on one saucer. There will be no cups or saucers left over.

questions.question_text: One-to-one correspondence means giving two objects to one person.
questions.explanation_correct: One-to-one correspondence means matching each object in one group to exactly one object in another group. It does not mean giving two objects to one person.
questions.explanation_incorrect: One-to-one correspondence is about matching objects one-to-one, not giving multiple objects to the same person. For example, if there are 4 cups and 4 saucers, each cup goes on one saucer. This helps us compare the groups and see if they have the same number of objects.

questions.question_text: If there are 6 birds and 4 nests, every bird will get a nest after one-to-one matching.
questions.explanation_correct: The answer is false because there are 6 birds but only 4 nests. This means that not every bird will get a nest after one-to-one matching, since there are fewer nests than birds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The answer is false because there are more birds than nests. After matching one bird to one nest, there will be 2 birds left over without a nest. This is because one-to-one matching means each object in one group goes with exactly one object in the other group, and there are not enough nests for all the birds.

questions.question_text: A brush and comb are a one-to-one pair like a cup and saucer.
questions.explanation_correct: A brush and comb are not a one-to-one pair like a cup and saucer. A one-to-one pair means each object in one group matches exactly one object in the other group. But a brush and comb are separate objects that do not match one-to-one.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A brush and comb are not a one-to-one pair like a cup and saucer. A one-to-one pair means that each cup has exactly one saucer that goes with it. But a brush and comb are not paired like that - they are just two separate objects that are used together, not in a one-to-one match.

questions.question_text: If 8 children each get 1 balloon from a bag of 8 balloons, the number of children and balloons is equal.
questions.explanation_correct: The number of children (8) and the number of balloons (8) is equal because each child gets one balloon. This is an example of one-to-one correspondence, where each object in one group is matched with exactly one object in the other group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the number of children (8) was not equal to the number of balloons (8), then there would not be one-to-one correspondence. For example, if there were only 7 balloons, then one child would not get a balloon. But in this case, the number of children and balloons is the same, so the statement is true.

questions.question_text: Matching objects one-to-one helps us learn to count.
questions.explanation_correct: Matching objects one-to-one helps us learn to count because it shows us how to pair up each object with one number. This helps us understand how many objects are in a group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Matching objects one-to-one does not directly help us learn to count. Counting involves saying the numbers out loud in order, one by one. While one-to-one correspondence can help us compare groups, it is not the same as learning to count.

questions.question_text: If there are 3 plates and 3 spoons, after matching one spoon to each plate, 1 spoon is left.
questions.explanation_correct: If there are 3 plates and 3 spoons, and we match one spoon to each plate, then all the spoons will be used. There will not be any spoons left over.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer is that 1 spoon is left. This is not correct because in one-to-one correspondence, each object in one group is matched to exactly one object in the other group. Since there are 3 plates and 3 spoons, all the spoons will be used, and there will not be any spoons left over.

questions.question_text: A group of 9 pencils and a group of 7 erasers have the same number when matched one-to-one.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is false because there are 9 pencils and only 7 erasers. When we match the pencils and erasers one-to-one, there will be 2 pencils left over. This means the groups do not have the same number of objects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false because the groups do not have the same number of objects. There are 9 pencils and only 7 erasers, so when we match them one-to-one, there will be 2 pencils left over. This means the groups have a different number of objects, not the same number.

questions.question_text: After matching one flower to each of 6 vases, and there are 6 flowers, every vase has a flower.
questions.explanation_correct: The answer is true because there are 6 flowers and 6 vases, and each flower is matched to one vase. This means that every vase has a flower in it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The answer is not false. Even though the number of flowers and vases are the same, this does not mean that not every vase has a flower. Since each flower is matched to one vase, and there are the same number of flowers and vases, every vase must have a flower in it.

questions.question_text: Touching each object once while saying a number is an example of one-to-one matching.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, that's right! When you touch each object once and say a number, you are matching each object to a specific number. This is an example of one-to-one matching, where each object is paired with exactly one other object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: No, that is not correct. One-to-one matching means that each object in one group is matched with exactly one object in another group. Touching each object while saying a number is not one-to-one matching, as you are only matching the objects to numbers, not to other objects.

questions.question_text: Put these steps in order to match 3 cups to 3 saucers one-to-one.
ordering_items: Place it on the last saucer
correct_answer: Place it on the last saucer
questions.explanation_correct: The steps are in the correct order because you need to pick up each cup one by one and place it on a separate saucer. This matches each cup to one saucer, which is one-to-one correspondence.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The steps are not in the correct order. You need to do the steps in the order: 1) Pick up the first cup, 2) Place it on a saucer, 3) Pick up the second cup, 4) Place it on another saucer, 5) Pick up the third cup, 6) Place it on the last saucer. This matches each cup to one saucer, which is one-to-one correspondence.

questions.question_text: Order these groups from fewest to most items.
questions.explanation_correct: The answer is correct because we arranged the groups from the fewest items (1 star) to the most items (5 stars). This shows that we understood one-to-one correspondence, which means matching each object in one group to exactly one object in another group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order is 1 star, 2 stars, 4 stars, 5 stars. This is because we need to arrange the groups from the fewest items to the most items. 1 star has the fewest items, then 2 stars, then 4 stars, and finally 5 stars has the most items. This shows that we understand one-to-one correspondence and can compare the number of items in each group.

questions.question_text: Put these steps in order to find out if 5 hats and 4 heads match equally.
ordering_items: Place one hat on the first head
Place one hat on the second head
Place one hat on the third head
Place one hat on the fourth head
See that 1 hat is left over
Conclude: there are more hats than heads
correct_answer: Place one hat on the first head
Place one hat on the second head
Place one hat on the third head
Place one hat on the fourth head
See that 1 hat is left over
Conclude: there are more hats than heads
questions.explanation_correct: The steps are in the right order because they show how to match each hat to one head. When all the hats are used but there is one head left, it means there are more hats than heads.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The steps are not in the right order. You need to first place one hat on each head, and then check if there are any hats left over. If there is one hat left over, it means there are more hats than heads. The correct order is: Place one hat on the first head, Place one hat on the second head, Place one hat on the third head, Place one hat on the fourth head, See that 1 hat is left over, Conclude: there are more hats than heads.

questions.question_text: Put these pairs in order from smallest number to largest number in each pair.
questions.explanation_correct: The answer is correct because each pair has the same number of objects. 1 shoe matches 1 foot, 2 shoes match 2 feet, 3 shoes match 3 feet, and 5 shoes match 5 feet. Putting them in order from smallest to largest number in each pair helps us see the one-to-one correspondence.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order is '1 shoe - 1 foot', '2 shoes - 2 feet', '3 shoes - 3 feet', '5 shoes - 5 feet'. This is because each pair has the same number of objects, and putting them in order from smallest to largest number in each pair shows the one-to-one correspondence between the shoes and feet. For example, 1 shoe matches 1 foot, 2 shoes match 2 feet, and so on.

questions.question_text: Order these matching activities from the smallest group to the largest group.
questions.explanation_correct: The answer is correct because the groups are ordered from the smallest (2 lids and 2 jars) to the largest (10 lids and 10 jars). This shows that one-to-one correspondence means matching each object in one group to exactly one object in another group, and the groups can be of different sizes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order is from the smallest group to the largest group. The order should be: 'Match 2 lids to 2 jars', 'Match 4 lids to 4 jars', 'Match 6 lids to 6 jars', and 'Match 10 lids to 10 jars'. This is because the number of lids and jars are the same in each group, showing that one-to-one correspondence is being used.

questions.question_text: After matching one-to-one, order these results from fewest left over to most left over.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is from fewest left over to most left over. In the first option, there are 5 balls and 5 boxes, so there are 0 left over. This is the fewest left over, so it comes first. The other options have 1, 2, and 3 left over, so the order is correct.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to order the options from most left over to fewest left over. This is wrong because the question asks to order from fewest left over to most left over. The correct order is 5 balls and 5 boxes: 0 left over, 6 balls and 5 boxes: 1 left over, 9 balls and 7 boxes: 2 left over, 7 balls and 4 boxes: 3 left over.

questions.question_text: Order these steps to pair socks with feet for 2 children.
ordering_items: Give 1 sock to Child 1 for the left foot
Give 1 sock to Child 1 for the right foot
Give 1 sock to Child 2 for the left foot
Give 1 sock to Child 2 for the right foot
correct_answer: Give 1 sock to Child 1 for the left foot
Give 1 sock to Child 1 for the right foot
Give 1 sock to Child 2 for the left foot
Give 1 sock to Child 2 for the right foot
questions.explanation_correct: The order is correct because each child needs 1 sock for their left foot and 1 sock for their right foot. This is a one-to-one matching, where each foot gets one sock.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order is incorrect because it does not match each child's feet to the correct socks. The steps should be: 1) Give 1 sock to Child 1 for the left foot, 2) Give 1 sock to Child 1 for the right foot, 3) Give 1 sock to Child 2 for the left foot, 4) Give 1 sock to Child 2 for the right foot. This way, each child's feet are matched with the correct socks.

questions.question_text: What is the the object it pairs with on the right of Cup?
questions.explanation_correct: The object that pairs with Cup is Saucer. This is because a cup and a saucer go together, like a pair. The cup sits on the saucer, so they match up in a one-to-one way.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options like Lock, Head, and Foot do not match with Cup. A cup is used with a saucer, not a lock, head, or foot. So the correct answer is Saucer, because a cup and saucer go together in a one-to-one way.

questions.question_text: What is the the object it pairs with on the right of Shoe?
questions.explanation_correct: The object that pairs with Shoe is Foot. This is because a shoe goes on your foot, so there is a one-to-one match between shoes and feet.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is Foot, not Lock, Head, or Saucer. A shoe is something you wear on your foot, so the object that matches with Shoe is Foot. The other options do not have a one-to-one relationship with Shoe.

questions.question_text: What is the the object it pairs with on the right of Key?
questions.explanation_correct: The object that pairs with the Key on the right is a Lock. This is because a key is used to open a lock, so they go together in a one-to-one correspondence.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The object that pairs with the Key is not a Foot, Saucer, or Head. These things do not have a direct connection or match with a Key. The correct answer is a Lock, because a key is used to open a lock, so they are paired together.

questions.question_text: What is the the object it pairs with on the right of Hat?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) Head. This is because a hat goes on your head, so there is a one-to-one correspondence between a hat and your head. The hat pairs with your head.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct. A saucer is something a cup goes on, not a hat. A foot is a different body part than a head. A lock is something you use to keep things safe, not something a hat pairs with. The correct answer is B) Head because a hat and your head go together.

questions.question_text: Which group does 2 dogs belong to?
questions.explanation_correct: The group that 2 dogs belong to is 2 bones. This is because each dog needs one bone, so the number of dogs (2) matches the number of bones (2). This is a one-to-one correspondence, where each object in one group is matched with exactly one object in the other group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options (5 spoons, 3 balloons, 4 nests) do not have a one-to-one correspondence with 2 dogs. This means that the number of objects in those groups does not match the number of dogs. Only the group of 2 bones has the same number of objects as the number of dogs, so that is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: Which group does 4 birds belong to?
questions.explanation_correct: The group that 4 birds belongs to is 4 nests. This is because each bird has its own nest, so there is a one-to-one match between the birds and the nests.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options do not match the number of birds. 5 spoons, 2 bones, and 3 balloons do not have a one-to-one match with 4 birds. The correct answer is 4 nests, because each bird has its own nest.

questions.question_text: Which group does 3 children belong to?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) 3 balloons. This is because the question asks 'Which group does 3 children belong to?' and 3 is the number of balloons in option C, which matches the number of children mentioned in the question.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options do not match the number of children mentioned in the question. Option A) 4 nests and option B) 5 spoons have a different number of objects, and option D) 2 bones also does not have 3 objects. So, the correct answer is 3 balloons in option C, as this matches the 3 children in the question.

questions.question_text: What is the what it practises on the right of Pointing to each toy and saying a number?
questions.explanation_correct: Pointing to each toy and saying a number is called one-to-one counting. This means you match each toy with one number, to keep track of how many toys there are. This helps you understand how many objects are in a group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: One-to-one sharing means giving each person in a group the same number of things, like sharing 4 cookies with 4 friends. One-to-one rhythm means clapping or tapping along with each object, like tapping for each toy you see. One-to-one matching means pairing up each object in one group with one object in another group, like matching each cup with a saucer. The correct answer is one-to-one counting, where you say a number for each toy to keep track of how many there are.

questions.question_text: What is the what it practises on the right of Placing one lid on each jar?
questions.explanation_correct: Placing one lid on each jar is an example of one-to-one matching. This means each object in one group (the jars) is matched with exactly one object in another group (the lids). This helps us see if the two groups have the same number of objects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A) One-to-one matching. This is because when you place one lid on each jar, you are making a one-to-one match between the jars and the lids. This is not about sharing, counting, or rhythm - it's about making sure each jar has exactly one lid.

questions.question_text: What is the what it practises on the right of Giving one sweet to each friend?
questions.explanation_correct: Giving one sweet to each friend is an example of one-to-one sharing. This means matching each object (the sweets) to each person (the friends), so that everyone gets exactly one sweet. This helps make sure everyone gets the same amount.
questions.explanation_incorrect: One-to-one rhythm is about keeping a steady beat, like in music. One-to-one counting is about counting objects one by one. One-to-one matching is about pairing up objects, like matching each cup with a saucer. Giving one sweet to each friend is about sharing the sweets evenly, which is an example of one-to-one sharing.

questions.question_text: What is the what it practises on the right of Clapping once for each step?
questions.explanation_correct: Clapping once for each step practices one-to-one rhythm. This means clapping matches each step with one clap, so the rhythm is in sync with the movement. This helps you keep a steady beat and understand how actions can match up one-to-one.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Clapping once for each step does not practice one-to-one matching, counting, or sharing. One-to-one matching is when each object in one group is paired with exactly one object in another group. One-to-one counting is when you say one number for each object you count. One-to-one sharing is when you give one object to each person. Clapping to the rhythm of steps is about keeping a steady beat, not these other one-to-one concepts.
